p.seg: TWENTY-SEVENTH ANNUAL REPORT OF THE Secretary of the State Banking Board SHOWING THE CONDITION OF THE Commercial and Savings Banks of Nebraska For the Year 1918 SUBMITTED TO THE STATE BANKING BOARD JANUARY 1, 1919. BY J. J. TOOLEY, Secretary THE KLINE PUBLISHING COMPANY Lincoln, Nebraska

TWENTY-SEVENTH ANNUAL REPORT OF THE 2 DEPARTMENT OF BANKING of the STATE OF NEBRASKA BOARD IION. KEITH NEVILLE Governor. Chairman IICN. WILLIAM H. SMITH Auditor of Public Accounts HON. WILLIS E. REED Attorney General J. J. TOO LEY Secretary MISS RUTH STREITZ Clerk MISS MAUDE HOGE Assistant Clerk MISS EMMA HAHLBECK Assistant Clerk MISS FAY FORBES Stenographer EXAMINERS J. II. DONNELLY A. D. TOUZALIN S. A. LAPP F. T. HOPKA T. P. SMITH H. B. GIPSON S. M. PATTERSON CHAS. R. WHITE M. R. SULLIVAN

SECRETARY OF THE STATE BANKING BOARD 3 STATE OF NEBRASKA DEPARTMENT OF BANKING Lincoln, January 1. 1919 To His Excellency, Keith Neville. Governor, Hon. Wm. H. Smith, Auditor of Public Accounts Hon. Willis E. Reed, Attorney General, Members of the State Banking Board. Sin: Herewith is transmitted the 27th annual report of the State Banking Department. In keeping with the true spirit of war-time economy, the report of 1917 was not published. This volume therefore includes sum - maries and certain statistical information covering a period of two years as well as a compilation of the last quarterly statements of the year which show the condition of each of the 934 banks operating under state authority at the close of business on November 1, 1918. During the biennium 110 new banks were opened for business, three voluntarily liquidated, while twelve consolidations were effected, thus producing a net gain in number of 95. The aggregate capital and sur - plus combined shows an increase of $5,302,288.66. Within the same period the total of deposits has advanced from $165,527,529.66 to $239. 815,362.70, a net increase of $74,287,833.04. The item of loans shows an increase of $69,259,639.46. The guaranty fund now aggregates $1,883, - 697.92, the increase for the two years being $689,773.44. These figures, while representing with reasonable accuracy the wonderful growth of the banking business during this period, do not by any means reflect the vast accumulations of wealth in the state. In this connection the fact must not be overlooked that the patrons of these banks have, without doubt, invested in government securities and contributed to other war funds, an amount at least equal to the increase shown in tota'. deposits. Then, too, only about one-half of the business of the state is done through state banks. Including these essential factors, an approximate estimate of the wealth accumulations of the people of the state may be made. In the analysis of the individual reports due allowance should be made for the call following so closely upon the Fourth Liberty Bond drive. In most cases the low reserves and excessive overdrafts are directly attributable to this fact. Since the date of the report, however, the Department has been advised of a return to more nearly normal conditions. The one big outstanding problem which has confronted the banker during the past year and a half, and in the solution of which he has been charged with a large measure of responsibility, has been that of the organization for, and the flotation by popular subscription of the four Liberty Loans. This service coupled with many others incident to the war has taxed hia ability and energy to the limit. It Is worthy of

4 TWENTY-SEVENTH ANNUAL REPORT OF THE tthat these gigantic tasks have been uniformly accepted in the light privilege as well as a duty. Instances have been rare indeed where ers faltered in the least or showed the slightest disinclination to >nd to any demand made upon their material resources or physical igth. These essential services have been performed with so little ay and so unselfishly as not to incite a single charge, so far as I r, of profiteering or even "patrioteering." This splendid and well ed record, together with a knowledge of the fact that our boys "over there," as well as those who. contrary to their own inclinations, were held "over here," were provided with every comfort, moral and physical, which kind hearts and money could provide, is sufficient com - pensation for all personal and financial sacrifices made necessary by the service. It is not my intention to eulogize the banker for the part he played in these great undertakings, as that would not be pleasing to him, but merely to direct attention to the most prominent facts as they have come to the knowledge of this Department. During this tense period when the minds, as well as the resources of all, were being absorbed by thoughts and demands of war, the De - partment has been able to do little more than sit tight in the boat and accept with becoming grace and fortitude the pleas of war demands and war activities as valid excuses for excess loans, overdrafts and de - layed reports. The times have not been considered propitious for the introduction of innovations or unproved theories, therefore none have been attempted. But now that the war is over the banker \r. admon - feto place his house in order in preparation for the changed condi - which peace shall bring. That such preparation is absolutely necessary and urgent is a universally accepted fact among men of vision and successful business experience. While not unmindful of the reluctance with which legislators ap - proach proposed amendments to the banking act, I am impelled to urge that some provision be made for disposing of the guaranty fund of liquidated banks. The law should also be amended making more specific the authority of the Banking Board in the adjustment of the guaranty fund of new banks as well as the equalization of the fund in different banks. I would further recommend incorporating in the law a provision clothing the Banking Board with authority to close up and liquidate insolvent banks. Under the present procedure a receivership means a long line of technical as well as useless court proceedings entailing un - necessary expense and consequent delay. While the Banking Board rep - resents the parties most in interest, the contributors to the guaranty fund, it surrenders all authority and jurisdiction the moment an institu - tion goes into the hands of a receiver and can only sit and await the deliberate movements of such receiver and the courts. I am not fully convinced that membership in the Federal Reserve System is of any advantage to state banks, yet if it is, conflicting requirements of the state and national law should be so adjusted as to make such mem - bership more inviting than at present. These suggestions are submitted

5 without argument, for such consideration as the legislature may, in its wisdom, decide to give them. In the administration of the affairs of the Banking Department too much emphasis cannot be placed upon the efficiency and high character of the examiners and the thoroughness with which they discharge their important duties. The men composing the present force measure up to all requirements fixed by these standards. The work of the examiners has been temporarily interrupted at intervals during the year by four resignations, all of which were accepted with reluctance. The first was that of Mr. E. E. Emraett. the oldest man in point of service on the force, who retired to accept a very inviting official position in a Linco'n bank Mr. S. M. Hall and Mr. J. H. Wehn both re-entered the banking business, while Mr. A. T. Nickerson responded to the call to military duty. Permit me in conclusion to express a keen sense of appreciation of the cordial and confidential relationship which at all times obtained between the Banking Board, the office force and myself. To me the pleasant, though sometimes strenuous, experiences afforded by the extra - ordinary conditions which have existed during my short period of service have indeed been worth while. Respectfully, J. J. TOOLEY. Secretary State Banking Board.
